data.title: Lake Erie: Sandusky, Ohio FM Bandscans
data.meta_description: A list of FM radio stations as commonly received in the East Harbor / Sandusky, Ohio area, part of a series of Great Lakes bandscans by Chris Kadlec.
data.meta_site_name: :: the online home of chris kadlec ::
data.text:
Go back to the Lake Erie bandscan series | Return to the coastal bandscans index

East Harbor State Park, in northern Ohio, is a radio site along the shores of Lake Erie eight miles northwest of Sandusky, home to the popular Cedar Point amusement park. Two scans were performed here at the very end of the radio season – a secondary scan during nighttime enhancement and a primary scan after the lake breeze circulation commenced in the late morning hours.

Being a peninsula with water on three sides, lake tropo is possible – and was present to a certain degree – to the north (Flint, Saginaw), the northwest (Lansing, Kalamazoo), the west (Fort Wayne, South Bend) as well as across the most open water to London, Buffalo, and Toronto, along with the most persistent shore-parallel reception to Cleveland and Erie. The location is boxed in by major metro areas, 60 miles from Cleveland and Detroit and 30 miles from Toledo, making reception all the more difficult. To add to the pain, enhanced conditions to Dayton and Columbus further crowded out possibilities both day and night thus hampering a more accurate understanding of how the water affects signals at East Harbor.

581 feet (12 feet above lake level)

Recommendations for this radio site: East Harbor State Park is a great place for radio work with the understanding that you are listening amidst major metro areas on all sides. Ohio State Parks offer relatively cheap camping with good amenities and this is a rather peaceful location for radio. Reserve a site and take a few minutes’ drive to the lakeshore to monitor signals or stay close to the campground with plenty of bathrooms nearby. As with most of Lake Erie’s shore, there is no beach and the site isn’t especially scenic compared to other sites.

For more scenic views, it’s absolutely worth a visit to Marblehead Lighthouse, a 10-15 minute drive to the east in view of the Cedar Point amusement park across the water. The lighthouse is part of a state park with free entrance and a fee of only a few dollars to climb the lighthouse. The park, despite its favourable location, is not recommended for radio listening due to the rather high volume of people. Down the road from the lighthouse is the Marblehead Quarry, which occupies a large chunk of the peninsula. Large freighters can sometimes be seen beside the Kelleys Island ferry dock (the island is also suitable for listening), all within a few minutes of the lighthouse.
